question: Which groups do you believe exist in your village?
answer: Well, from what I have observed so far, there seems to be a tight-knit community in this village. There are the young students, like myself, who attend Oak Hill College, the locals who have been living here for generations, and the retirees who have chosen this peaceful village as their new home. I have also heard about a group of artists and musicians who are very active in the village, organizing cultural events and gatherings. I'm sure there are many other groups that I have yet to uncover during my exploration.

question: Which group do you think you belong to?
answer: Well, I am a student at Oak Hill College, so I guess I belong to the young student group. But I also feel a connection to the artists and musicians in the village, especially since I love exploring literature, as I'm sure they do as well. Wolfgang and I have been discussing Shakespeare's works and we plan on visiting the local library to learn more about the village's love for literature. We also plan on having lunch at Hobbs Cafe, so we can not only try their famous pumpkin spice latte, but also support a local business. And of course, we are excited to attend Sam's birthday party at The Rose and Crown Pub. We want to immerse ourselves in the community and get to know the people who call this village home.

question: How would you describe the differences between your group and others?
answer: I believe the biggest difference between my group of students and the other groups in the village is our age and stage in life. We are still studying and trying to figure out our paths in the world, while the locals and retirees have already established themselves in this village and have their own routines and responsibilities. As for the artists and musicians, they seem to have a more creative and free-spirited approach to life compared to us students. However, I think we all come together in our love for this village and our desire to support and learn from each other.

question: How important is it to you that others understand which group you belong to?
answer: To me, it's not crucial that others understand which group I belong to. What's more important to me is building genuine connections with the people here in the village, regardless of which group they belong to. I believe that through our shared experiences and interactions, we can learn and appreciate each other's differences and come together as one community.

question: To what extent do members of other groups treat you differently than members of your own group?
answer: I am fortunate enough to have met members of different groups in this village and I have not noticed any significant difference in their treatment towards me based on my group. Everyone I have interacted with has been welcoming and friendly so far, and I am grateful for their openness. I believe the importance of genuine human connections surpasses any preconceived notions or stereotypes based on our group affiliations. As a newcomer, I am just happy to have the opportunity to learn from and connect with residents from various backgrounds in this village.
